objinfo.printdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression was printed in 1795. This is the only extant impression from this printing session. Butlin 304 suggests that there may have been another impression shown to John Ruskin c. 1843 and later owned by Arthur Burgess, who died in 1887. If such an impression did exist, it was very probably printed in 1795.
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color, black chalk, and pen and ink additions to the impression

provenance.name: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
provenance.note: Probably acquired by Blake's wife, Catherine, upon his death in 1827; probably acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Mrs. Blake's death in 1831; sold from Tatham's collection, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 190 (£4 to Francis Turner Palgrave); sold c. 1873 to Henry Adams; his niece Mrs. Robert Homans (née Abigail Adams), probably by inheritance in 1918; given by Mrs. Homans to the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, in 1927.

objnote.p: The subject of "Nebuchadnezzar" is derived from the biblical Book of Daniel, 4:31-33. A "voice from heaven" tells the Babylonian monarch that he will "be with the beasts of the field." The prophecy is fulfilled immediately, and Nebuchadnezzar grows "hairs ... like eagles' feathers" and "nails like birds' claws." For Blake, this image probably represented the descent of a mighty ruler, and perhaps all of humanity, into a state of fallen nature.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Nebuchadnezzar, transformed into a nude, beast-like figure with claw-like nails and long, shaggy hair and beard, crawls towards the right but turns his head to face the viewer. His face, eyes looking out at the viewer, expresses sorrow and despair. Feather-like fur covers part of his body and upper legs. He crawls along the ground in front of the trunks of two large trees that lean together and form a cave-like space between them. There may be some (dead or dying?) vegetation on the ground below Nebuchadnezzar.

component.illusobjdesc: Nebuchadnezzar, transformed into a muscular nude, beast-like figure with spiky claw-like nails on his hands and feet and long, shaggy hair and beard, crawls towards the right with his head turned to face the viewer. His long hair cascades over his neck and upper back. His hands are on the ground with his fingers together. His right arm is slightly before his left arm. Feather-like fur covers part of Nebuchadnezzar’s lower torso and continues to his knees. His right leg is extended behind his left leg. His right foot has its toes spread on tiptoe, perhaps digging into the ground. His facial expression is a mixture of despair and sorrow; his eyes look blankly toward the viewer. Lines below his eyes might indicate the flow of tears.
The trunks of two large trees lean towards each other behind Nebuchadnezzar. They form a dark cave-like space between them, visible below Nebuchadnezzar's stomach.
There are slight indictations of (dead or dying?) vegetation on the ground below Nebuchadnezzar, possibly including short vines, moss, lichens, or grass.
The dark areas along the left margin and upper right may represent a dark sky (at night?).
